Situation1: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Situation2: The taxi driver ensures the cab remains neat and hygienic.
Story: I sat behind the wheel, my hands gripping it tighter than usual. My boyfriend was in the back seat, his arms crossed, his jaw set. We’d just had another argument—this one worse than the rest. He accused me of never listening, of caring more about my job than about us. I wanted to turn around, to reach out and fix things, to show him I could resolve this, that I cared. But the meter was running, and my next passenger was due in ten minutes. The back seat was a mess—crumbs from his snack, a spilled coffee on the floor mat. As a taxi driver, I was expected to keep my cab spotless, to greet every customer with a smile, to be professional no matter what. But right now, my heart was pounding, torn between cleaning up the mess and cleaning up the mess between us. I could feel his eyes on me, waiting for me to say something, to choose him. But the clock was ticking, and I didn’t know which role to answer first.
